newsitem.title: UNITED NATIONS: Traffic lights to limit Earth summit speeches.
newsitem.headline: Traffic lights to limit Earth summit speeches.

text.p: Organisers of the 173-nation second Earth Summit, worried about rhetorical overload, have installed a traffic light to keep speakers under control.

U.N. General Assembly President Razali Ismail of Malaysia said a green light marked the start of a speaker's address, orange indicated 30 seconds remained, and red meant the allotted seven minutes was up.
He did not say what would happen to offenders who jumped a red light.

Organisers are keenly aware of the danger of speakers running over their time at the week-long meeting, where more than 60 heads of state or government are taking part in a special session of the General Assembly to review progress made since the first Earth Summit in Rio de Janeiro in 1992.
